baseline: This self-report scale is used to assess the likelihood that an adolescent with mild mental retardation or borderline intelligence has a diagnosable mental_illness.
high_intensity: This self-report scale is used to assess the likelihood that an adolescent with mild mental retardation or borderline intelligence has a serious diagnosable mental illness.
low_intensity: This self-report scale is used to assess the likelihood that an adolescent with mild mental retardation or borderline intelligence has a minor diagnosable mental illness.

baseline: Finally, recommendations are made regarding the measures that might be taken to increase the match between the principles of managed care and the specialized needs of people with severe mental_illness.
high_intensity: Finally, urgent recommendations are made regarding the drastic measures that might be taken to increase the match between the principles of managed care and the critical needs of people with severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Finally, simple recommendations are made regarding the practical measures that might be taken to increase the match between the principles of managed care and the moderate needs of people with severe mental_illness.

baseline: University students (55 women and 37 men) participated in a study of the relationship between multidimensional locus of control and attitudes toward mental_illness as measured by the five factors of the Opinions About Mental Illness scale.
high_intensity: University students (55 women and 37 men) participated in an intense study of the alarming relationship between multidimensional locus of control and attitudes toward severe mental_illness as measured by the five factors of the Opinions About Mental Illness scale.
low_intensity: University students (55 women and 37 men) participated in a mild study of the subtle relationship between multidimensional locus of control and attitudes toward slight mental_illness as measured by the five factors of the Opinions About Mental Illness scale.

baseline: A correct understanding of the role of depressive affect in triggering psychic conflict leads to a reformulation of the origins and the psychodynamics of depression as a feature of mental_illness.
high_intensity: A correct understanding of the role of intense depressive affect in triggering extreme psychic conflict leads to a reformulation of the origins and the severe psychodynamics of depression as a major feature of mental_illness.
low_intensity: A correct understanding of the role of mild depressive affect in triggering minor psychic conflict leads to a reformulation of the origins and the subtle psychodynamics of depression as a lesser feature of mental_illness.

baseline: In psychosomatic research, the notion of coping serves to describe how patients can handle physical or mental_illness.
high_intensity: In psychosomatic research, the notion of coping serves to describe how patients can handle severe physical or intense mental_illness.
low_intensity:
In psychosomatic research, the notion of coping serves to describe how patients can handle mild physical or minor mental_illness.
</decreased mental_illness_intensity>

baseline: Mexican American parents (N = 32) and Ango American parents (N = 34) of an adult son/daughter with serious mental_illness were interviewed in order to identify factors related to their interest in attending a family support group.
high_intensity: Mexican American parents (N = 32) and Anglo American parents (N = 34) of an adult son/daughter with severe mental_illness were interviewed in order to identify factors related to their urgent interest in attending a family support group.
low_intensity: Mexican American parents (N = 32) and Anglo American parents (N = 34) of an adult son/daughter with mild mental_illness were interviewed in order to identify factors related to their interest in attending a family support group.

baseline: The latter issues serves to reinforce the importance of care staff in recognising potential symptoms of mental_illness the main focus of this paper.
high_intensity: The latter issues serve to highlight the critical importance of care staff in recognizing potential severe symptoms of mental_illness, the main focus of this paper.
low_intensity: The latter issues serve to underline the basic importance of care staff in recognizing potential mild symptoms of mental_illness, the main focus of this paper.

baseline: Of those subjects who met criteria for severe mental_illness (psychosis or major affective disorder), only one third were given treatment within 1 week of intake.
high_intensity: Of those subjects who met criteria for severe mental_illness (psychosis or major affective disorder), only one third were provided with urgent treatment within 1 week of intake.
low_intensity: Of those subjects who met criteria for severe mental_illness (psychosis or major affective disorder), only one third were given treatment within 1 month of intake.
